ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Tin oxide nanocrystals embedded in nanopore arrays on stainless steel surface for photocatalytic applications

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Key Laboratory for Ferrous Metallurgy and Resource Utilization of Ministry of Education
Affiliation.OrgName: Wuhan University of Science and Technology

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: The immobilization of SnO2 nanocrystals on solid substrates for practical photocatalytic applications suffers from poor adhesion that will lead to loss of photocatalytic activity and short service life. An efficient hydrothermal synthesis of SnO2 nanocrystals embedded in nanopore arrays on stainless steel surface was presented in this paper. The morphology, chemical composition and microstructure of the embedded tin oxide nanocrystals were investigated by X-ray diffraction, field-emission scanning electron microscope, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and UV-visible diffuse reflectance spectroscopy. The photocatalytic activity and stability of SnO2 nanocrystals was evaluated by photodegradation of methylene blue. SnO2 nanocrystals embedded in nanopore arrays on stainless steel surface existed in a tetragonal rutile structure. The increasing of the hydrothermal temperature will lead to the improvement in photocatalytic activity of SnO2 nanocrystals. The SnO2 nanocrystals prepared at 220 °C performed the highest photocatalytic activity and good photocatalytic stability, indicating the effective immobilization of SnO2 nanocrystals on anodized stainless steel.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Tin oxide, an n-type semiconductor [1–3] with a wide band gap (3.6 eV), has been extensively employed in gas sensing [4], electronics [5], and photonics [6] owing to its chemical stability, superior optical and electrical properties. It is also a favorable photocatalyst for decontamination, purification, and deodorization of air and wastewater [7, 8]. However, the application of powdered photocatalyst in an aqueous suspension has a drawback of the expensive and complex post-separation after photoreaction [9, 10]. Efforts have been made to immobilize tin oxide on stainless steels, which are highly stable in aqueous solution during photocatalytic process [11, 12]. However, the immobilization suffers from poor adhesion of tin oxide nanocrystals to the high polish stainless steel surface that will lead to loss of photocatalytic activity and short service life of the immobilized photocatalyst.

In situ growth of nanopore arrays on metal substrate is beneficial for the immobilization of nanocrystals or biomolecules on the surface [13, 14]. Aligned nanopore arrays on stainless steel surface can be fabricated by electrochemical anodization [15, 16]. There are several techniques to synthesize SnO2 nanocrystals, including sol–gel techniques [17–19], chemical vapor deposition [20, 21], laser ablation technique [22] and hydrothermal treatment [1–3]. Among these techniques, hydrothermal treatment shows advantages such as simple equipment without high vacuum or heating temperature, large quantity of photocatalyst with controllable structure and highly homogeneous crystal quality [23, 24]. In this paper, we present an efficient hydrothermal synthesis of tin oxide nanocrystals embedded in nanopore arrays, which were prepared by electrochemical anodization on stainless steel surface. The embedded tin oxide nanocrystals showed excellent photocatalytic activity as well as good photocatalytic stability, indicating the effective immobilization of tin oxide nanocrystals. The morphology, chemical composition and microstructure of the embedded tin oxide nanocrystals are investigated.

Section2.Heading: Preparation of SnO2 nanocrystals
Section2.Para: Mechanically polished 316L stainless steel foil (15×20×0.5 mm) was electropolished in ethylene glycol (EG) solution containing 5 vol% perchloric acid at 20 V for 20 min. The foil was then anodized in a 0.3 mol/L sodium dihydrogen phosphate solution at 5 °C at 30 V for 20 min. After anodization, the anodized foil was cleaned in a sonicator with ethanol followed by double distilled water (DDW). The cleaned foil was then put in a 60-mL Teflon-lined stainless autoclave. Deposition of SnO2 nanocrystals was carried out by hydrothermal reaction in a precursor solution, at the temperatures of 70, 120, 170 and 220 °C, respectively. The precursor solution was prepared by dissolving 0.42 g of SnCl4⋅5H2O, 0.48 g of NaOH and 0.028 g of NaC12H25SO4 (SDS) in 40 mL DDW. After 10 min ultrasonic dispersing, the mixture was transferred into the above autoclave and heated for 3 h at various temperatures. The resulting sample was cooled down naturally to room temperature, followed by washing with DDW and drying at 50 °C for 1 h. All chemicals were of analytical grade.

Section2.Heading: Nanocrystals characterization and photocatalytic test
Section2.Para: The morphology of SnO2 nanocrystals was conducted by a field-emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM, FEI Nova 400 Nano). X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern was performed on a XPERT PRO MRD diffractometer using Cu–Ka radiation (40 kV, 20 mA, λ=1.5406 Å). Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area was investigated with a specific surface area analyzer (SSA-4300, Builder, China). The UV-vis diffuse reflection spectra were recorded on a UV-vis spectrophotometer (TU 1901, Beijing Purkinje General Instrument Co., China) using the anodized sample as the reflectance sample. The electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) were evaluated in a 5 mg/L MB aqueous solution using a conventional three-electrode system, with stainless steel specimen as the working electrode, a platinum wire as the counter electrode and a standard calomel electrode as the reference. EIS measurements were carried out on a CHI660E potentiostat with a frequency range of 0.1 Hz to 100 kHz, amplitude 10 mV at the open circuit potential at the rate of 5 mV/s at room temperature.

Methylene blue (MB) was chosen as the model contaminant. The photocatalytic activities of the samples were estimated by UV irradiation in 10 mL 5 mg/L MB solution in a quartz reactor at room temperature. The UV lamp was 2 cm away from the reactor. The reactor was kept in dark for 1 h to establish adsorption equilibrium for all samples before measurement. The absorption of MB solution was evaluated by a UV-vis spectrophotometer (TU 1901, Beijing Purkinje General Instrument Co., China) every 30 min under its maximum absorption wavelength (λ max=664 nm). Control experiments were carried out with commercial Degussa P-25 nanoparticles (75 % in anatase phase and 25 % in rutile) which were totally deposited on anodized stainless steel. The photodegradation of MB is presented by the coordinates C/C 0 vs. time and ln(C 0/C) vs. time, where C 0 and C are the concentrations at the initial and the measurement time. To investigate the pH effect on photocatalytic activity of SnO2 film on anodized stainless steel, MB solution was adjusted by adding 0.2 M NaOH and HCl to change the pH value.

Section1.Heading: Results and discussion
Section1.Para:
Figure 1 presents XRD patterns of the samples prepared at 70, 120, 170 and 220 °C by hydrothermal reaction. XRD patterns of samples prepared at 70 and 120 °C are almost the same as those of anodized stainless steel in terms of shape and position of the characteristic diffraction peaks, indicating that the hydrothermal reaction did not occur at such temperatures. The diffraction peaks associated with tetragonal rutile SnO2 phase (PDF 770450) [25] occurred when the temperature increased to 170 and 220 °C. The XRD pattern of the sample prepared at 220 °C showed an increase of intensity of SnO2 diffraction peaks, as compared to the sample prepared at 170 °C, corresponding to the higher crystallinity. On the other hand, the average crystallite sizes of SnO2 of 220 °C sample (53 nm) was larger than that of 170 °C sample (47 nm), when viewing from the (110), (101) and (211) peaks. The values of the crystallite sizes of SnO2 were estimated according to the Scherrer formula: D=Kαλ/(β×cosθ). The BET surface areas were 2.0 and 2.2 m2/g for 170 and 220 °C specimens, respectively. The hydrothermal temperature increased, the BET surface area increased.
Fig. 1
XRD patterns of (1) anodized stainless steel and the samples prepared at (2) 70 °C, (3) 120 °C, (4) 170 °C and (5) 220 °C, with reflection from SnO2 (PDF No. 01-077-0447) and Austenite stainless steel (PDF No. 00-031-0619)

Morphology of the samples prepared at 70, 120, 170 and 220 °C is shown in Fig. 2. Uniform nanopore arrays that are mainly composed of Fe2O3 and Cr2O3 [16] with diameter ranging from approx. 100 to 200 nm were obtained on stainless steel surface after electrochemical anodization. Morphology was almost unchanged after hydrothermal reaction at 70 and 120 °C, suggesting that SnO2 nanocrystals did not deposit on the nanopore arrays. The results are consistent with XRD patterns, showing that hydrothermal reaction did not occur at 70 and 120 °C. Flower-like SnO2 nanocrystals with an average diameter of 2 μm were observed on the sample prepared at 170 and 220 °C. Crystallinity of the sample prepared at 220 °C was higher than that of the sample prepared at 170 °C, resulting in uniform nanorods with sectional side length of 300∼500 nm.
Fig. 2
FESEM images of samples: (a) anodized stainless steel, (b–e) the samples prepared at 70, 120, 170 and 220 °C

Chemical composition of SnO2 nanocrystals was analyzed by XPS (Fig. 3). The high resolution XPS spectra of the O and Sn elements are shown in Fig. 3, b and c, respectively. The O 1s spectra presented two deconvoluted binding energy peaks at 530.2 and 531.3 eV, which should be attributed to the oxygen in SnO2 and the adsorbed hydroxyl species, respectively [26, 27]. The two peaks of Sn-3d with binding energy of 486.4 and 494.8 eV were attributed to Sn(IV) 3d5/2 and 3d3/2, respectively [23]. The spectrum confirmed the presence of the SnO2 in the sample, and no characteristic diffraction peak corresponding to SnO or Sn [24] was observed.
Fig. 3
XPS spectra of SnO2 film prepared at the 220 °C, survey spectrum (a), O 1s (b), Sn 3d (c)

UV-vis DRS spectra of samples are shown in Fig. 4. The SnO2 nanocrystals on stainless steel prepared at 170 and 220 °C showed intense absorption with much higher absorbance than the samples prepared at 70 and 120 °C. The red shift in absorbance of samples prepared at 170 and 220 °C could be attributed to the well-formed SnO2 nanocrystals that are favorable for the improvement of the photocatalytic activity of SnO2 [28]. As a crystalline direct semiconductor [1, 29], the values of the band gap energy of SnO2 on anodized stainless steel were estimated according to the equation α(hν)=A(hν−E g)1/2, in which hν is the photon energy, E g the apparent optical band gap, A a constant characteristic of the semiconductor, and α the adsorption coefficient. Figure 4 shows the graphs of (αhν)2 vs. photon energy hν for SnO2 on anodized stainless steel under different hydrothermal temperatures. The estimated band gap energies were therefore about 2.48, 3.43 and 3.34 eV for the resulting specimens under of 120, 170 and 220 °C, respectively. The optical band gap of the 220 °C specimen is less than that of the 170 °C specimen. It should be attributed to the crystallite size effect.
Fig. 4
UV-vis spectra of the samples referred to anodized stainless steel, (1–4) the samples prepared at 70, 120, 170 and 220 °C

Figure 5 shows typical Nyquist plots for the SnO2 specimens at different hydrothermal temperature. The charge transfer resistance (R ct) of the specimens was investigated by analyzing the EIS spectra [30]. The R ct decreased with increase of the hydrothermal temperature. The R ct values of SnO2 nanocrystals on stainless steel prepared at 220 °C were ∼20 times lower than of the samples prepared at 70 and 120 °C, indicating the much higher conductivity of SnO2 film prepared at 220 °C. The high conductive SnO2 film is favorable for the transport of photogenerated electrons and can therefore facilitate the separation of photogenerated electron–hole pairs.
Fig. 5
Nyquist plots of anodized stainless steel and the samples prepared at 70, 120, 170 and 220 °C

The MB degradation of the samples under UV light irradiation is illustrated in Fig. 6. The MB degradation followed pseudo-first-order kinetics [31] is shown in Fig. 6b. The degradation rate constant is estimated to be 5.8×10−4, 21.9×10−4, 28.3×10−4, 43.3×10−4, 61.8×10−4 and 39×10−4 min−1 for the anodized stainless steel and the samples prepared at 70, 120, 170, 220, and P-25, respectively. With the increase of hydrothermal reaction temperature, the photocatalytic activity of the samples increased accordingly. The sample prepared at 220 °C exhibited the maximum photocatalytic activity [29], which should be attributed to the favorable crystal structure, high surface area, and high conductivity that can facilitate the separation of photogenerated electron–hole pairs. The photocatalytic activity of SnO2 films prepared at 220 °C is comparable to some recent progress of SnO2 nanomaterials [30, 32].
Fig. 6
Effects of samples on C/C 0 of MB (a) and ln(C 0/C) of MB for samples (b); (1) anodized stainless steel, (2–5) the samples prepared at 70, 120, 170 and 220 °C

The photocatalytic stability of SnO2 nanocrystals on anodized stainless steel prepared at 220 °C was also investigated. The recycling experiments of the sample were performed under the same conditions as the above photocatalytic test. The results from recycling experiment are shown in Fig. 7a. After five recycles for the photodegradation of MB, the photocatalytic activity did not exhibit a significant loss. This result indicates that embedded SnO2 nanocrystals on anodized stainless steel were not photocorroded during the photocatalytic oxidation of MB. To further understand the degradation mechanism of MB over the SnO2 on anodized stainless steel, the effect of the pH value of the MB solution on photocatalytic system was investigated (Fig. 7b). It can be seen that the photocatalytic degradation of MB was almost unaffected by the addition of H+ (pH=5). The photocatalytic degradation of MB decreased obviously with the addition of OH− (pH=9), because OH• and h+ were the main active species for SnO2 in aqueous solution under UV light irradiation [1, 3, 30]. The CB (0 eV) of SnO2 was more positive than
${\mathrm{O}_{2}} / {\mathrm{O}_{2}^{\bullet}}$ (−0.05 eV), while the VB (3.34 eV) was more positive than •OH/OH− (2.38 eV vs. NHE). Therefore, the holes on VB reacted with H2O to obtain OH• and h+ under UV light irradiation.
Fig. 7
(a) The average degradation of MB on SnO2 film prepared at 220 °C at different recycling runs; (b) The effect of the pH value on photocatalytic activity of SnO2 film prepared at 220 °C

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: An efficient hydrothermal synthesis of SnO2 nanocrystals embedded in nanopore arrays on stainless steel surface was presented. The samples were characterized by XRD, FESEM, XPS and UV-Vis DRS. The effects of hydrothermal temperature on the morphology and photocatalytic activity of samples were analyzed. The embedded SnO2 nanocrystals showed excellent photocatalytic activity as well as good photocatalytic stability, indicating the effective immobilization of SnO2 nanocrystals on anodized stainless steel surface for practical photocatalytic applications.
